channel.title: Linux on a calculator?
channel.description:
I own a TI-84 calculator, and I was wondering: is it possible to run Linux on it? I know this sounds odd, useless, stupid, etc but AFAIK it should be possible. It's supposed to have a 15Mhz CPU, according to http://www.datamath.org/Graphing/TI-84PLUS.htm
Of course, the problem would be to get Linux on it. So yea, am I proving I'm a retard or is this possible?

item.title: Linux on a calculator?
item.dc:creator: @Cheese_Police c|p
item.description:
@Cheese_Police wrote:

R.I.P RSC:

But I’m beginning to doubt wheter it has enough storage room.

that is like, but if you use an older kernel (smaller) and take out tons of shit you dont need (mainly drivers), you might be able to make it small enough.

Read full topic

item.title: Linux on a calculator?
item.dc:creator: @bootnecklad bootnecklad
item.description:
@bootnecklad wrote:

[quote=“R.I.P RSC, post:10, topic:267274”]lawl, just as bootnecklad said, I bother because I can. Why make a cpu out of relays? Because you can. On top of that, it proves again that Linux is compatible on many architectures.

But I’m beginning to doubt wheter it has enough storage room.[/quote]

Not knowing anything about it but you could probably get a chip or something and put linux on it and use the in built chip to read it from the chip with linux on… Just an idea.

Read full topic

why bother?

why we cheat?
[/quote]
we cheat for an advantage, and cause of lazyness.
linux wont give you an advantage here…[/quote]

item.title: Linux on a calculator?
item.dc:creator: @ilyaostr9 io9
item.description:
@ilyaostr9 wrote:

en.wikipedia.org

TI PLT SHH1

TI PLT SHH1 (Personal Learning Tool, Spot Hand Held) is a prototype calculator created by Texas Instruments as an early attempt to develop a Linux-based calculator. It features an ARM based OMAP 1510 processor, 16 MB RAM, and an SD slot. In conjunction with its TI PLT-FHH1 Personal Learning Tool, Fido Hand Held and TI PLT-SU1 Personal Learning Tool, second generation are prototype calculators. The project was eventually scrapped by TI in early 2004. However, a few of the early prototypes such as ...

Linux, you say?

Read full topic

not sure about linux, but theres mirage OS, which you can install on your calculator and you can get many games.

item.title: Linux on a calculator?
item.dc:creator: @Cheese_Police c|p
item.description:
@Cheese_Police wrote:

The clock speed of the Z-80 compatible microprocessor raised to 15 MHz compared to the 6 MHz of the elder TI-83 products.

afaik there isn’t a distro compatible with the z-80 architecture, you might be able to find something.

you might be able to make a “linux” application for it, by that i mean, mimic a terminal.

Read full topic
